title: 112_s1085
content:
There is no text provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. NEXT GENERATION BIOFUEL." The Clean Air Act is amended to redefine "next generation biofuel" as renewable fuel derived from cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, or algae from renewable biomass. This redefinition is part of the section on next generation biofuel standards. The Clean Air Act is amended to redefine "next generation biofuel" as renewable fuel derived from cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, or algae from renewable biomass. This redefinition includes changes to terminology in various clauses and headings. The Clean Air Act is amended to replace "cellulosic" with "next generation" in various clauses and headings, including paragraphs (3)(A), (4)(A), and (4)(B). This redefinition also applies to paragraph (7)(D) where "cellulosic" is replaced with "next generation". The Clean Air Act is amended to replace "cellulosic" with "next generation" in various clauses and headings, including paragraphs (3)(A), (4)(A), and (4)(B). This redefinition also applies to paragraph (7)(D) where "cellulosic" is replaced with "next generation". Additionally, there is a provision for states to opt out of the Renewable Fuel Standard. The Clean Air Act is amended to allow states to opt out of the Renewable Fuel Standard by passing a law and obtaining the Governor's signature. This adjustment will affect the applicable volume of renewable fuel determined under the Act. The Administrator may allow a State to not participate in the applicable volume of renewable fuel determined under the Renewable Fuel Standard, except for certain required volumes. The Administrator may allow a State to not participate in the applicable volume of renewable fuel determined under the Renewable Fuel Standard, except for certain required volumes. If a State elects not to participate, the Administrator will calculate credits for gasoline provided through a fuel terminal in the State as if it were blended fuel. The Administrator may calculate the State's renewable fuel volume based on the maximum ethanol content allowed in the State for blending with gasoline.
